Online Posterior Sampling with a Diffusion Prior

Branislav Kveton
AWS AI Labs &Boris Oreshkin
Amazon &Youngsuk Park
AWS AI Labs &Aniket Deshmukh
AWS AI Labs &Rui Song
Amazon
Abstract

Posterior sampling in contextual bandits with a Gaussian prior can be implemented exactly or approximately using the Laplace approximation. The Gaussian prior is computationally efficient but it cannot describe complex distributions. In this work, we propose approximate posterior sampling algorithms for contextual bandits with a diffusion model prior. The key idea is to sample from a chain of approximate conditional posteriors, one for each stage of the reverse process, which are estimated in a closed form using the Laplace approximation. Our approximations are motivated by posterior sampling with a Gaussian prior, and inherit its simplicity and efficiency. They are asymptotically consistent and perform well empirically on a variety of contextual bandit problems.

1 Introduction

A multi-armed bandit [26, 6, 29] is an online learning problem where an agent sequentially interacts with an environment over nğ‘›nitalic_n rounds with the goal of maximizing its rewards. In each round, it takes an action and receives its stochastic reward. The mean rewards of the actions are unknown a priori and must be learned. This leads to the exploration-exploitation dilemma: explore actions to learn about them or exploit the action with the highest estimated reward. Bandits have been successfully applied to problems where uncertainty modeling and adaptation to it are beneficial, such as in recommender systems [31, 53, 24, 34] and hyper-parameter optimization [33].

Contextual bandits [28, 31] with linear [13, 1] and generalized linear models (GLMs) [16, 32, 2, 25] have become popular due to the their flexibility and efficiency. The features in these models can be hand-crafted or learned from historic data [39], and the models can be also updated incrementally [1, 23]. While the original algorithms for linear and GLM bandits were based on upper confidence bounds (UCBs) [13, 1, 16], Thompson sampling (TS) is more popular in practice [11, 3, 41, 43]. The key idea in TS is to explore by sampling from the posterior distribution of model parameter Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. TS uses the prior knowledge about Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to speed up exploration [11, 39, 35, 9, 20, 19, 5]. When the prior is a multivariate Gaussian, the posterior of Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be updated and sampled from efficiently [11]. Unfortunately, this prior has limited expressive power, because it cannot even represent multimodal distributions. To address this limitation, we study posterior sampling with complex priors.

We make the following contributions. First, we propose novel posterior sampling approximations for linear models and GLMs with a diffusion model prior. The key idea is to sample from a chain of approximate conditional posteriors, one for each stage of the reverse process, which are estimated in a closed form. In linear models, each conditional is a product of two Gaussians, representing prior knowledge and diffused evidence (TheoremÂ 2). In GLMs, each conditional is obtained by a Laplace approximation, which mixes prior knowledge and evidence (TheoremÂ 4). Our approximations are motivated by posterior sampling with a Gaussian prior, and inherit its simplicity and efficiency. The prior works (SectionÂ 7) rely on the score of the likelihood of observations. In online learning, the likelihood score tends to infinity as the number of observations increases, which causes divergence of the existing approximations (SectionÂ 6.2).

Our second major contribution is in theory. More specifically, we prove that our posterior approximation is asymptotically consistent (TheoremÂ 3). The key idea in the proof is that the conditional posteriors in TheoremÂ 2 concentrate at a scaled unknown model parameter as the number of observations increases. While this claim is asymptotic, it is an expected property of a posterior distribution. Many prior works, such as Chung etÂ al. [12], do not poses this property.

Our last contribution is empirical evaluation on contextual bandit problems. We focus on bandits because the ability to represent all levels of uncertainty well is critical for exploration. Our experiments (SectionÂ 6.2) show that a score-based method fails to do so. Note that our posterior approximations are general and not restricted to bandits.

2.3 Towards Diffusion Model Priors

The assumption that pâ¢(Î¸âˆ—)=ğ’©â¢(Î¸âˆ—;Î¸0,Î£0)ğ‘subscriptğœƒğ’©subscriptğœƒsubscriptğœƒ0subscriptÎ£0p(\theta_{*})=\mathcal{N}(\theta_{*};\theta_{0},\Sigma_{0})italic_p ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is limiting, for instance because it precludes multimodal priors. We relax it by representing pâ¢(Î¸âˆ—)ğ‘subscriptğœƒp(\theta_{*})italic_p ( italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by a diffusion model, which we call a diffusion model prior. We propose an efficient posterior sampling approximation for this prior where the prior and empirical evidence are mixed similarly to (3) and ğ™¸ğšğ™»ğš‚ğ™¸ğšğ™»ğš‚\tt IRLStypewriter_IRLS (SectionÂ 4). Before we do this, we review diffusion models in SectionÂ 3.

3 Diffusion Models

A diffusion model [45, 18] is a generative model trained by diffusing samples from an unknown distribution. While multiple types of diffusion models exist [48], we adopt the probabilistic formulation and presentation of Ho etÂ al. [18]. A diffusion model is a graphical model with Tğ‘‡Titalic_T stages indexed by tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ]. Each stage tğ‘¡titalic_t is associated with a latent variable Stâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘‘S_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A sample from the model is represented by an observed variable S0âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘†0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘S_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We visualize the diffusion model in FigureÂ 1. In the forward process, the sample s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is diffused through a sequence of variables S1,â€¦,STsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘‡S_{1},\dots,S_{T}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This process is used to learn the reverse process, where the sample s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated through a sequence of variables ST,â€¦,S0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘‡â€¦subscriptğ‘†0S_{T},\dots,S_{0}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To sample s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the posterior (SectionÂ 4), we add a random variable Hğ»Hitalic_H, which represents partial information about s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We introduce forward and reverse diffusion processes next. Learning of the reverse process is described in AppendixÂ B. While this is a critical component of diffusion models, it is not necessary to introduce our posterior approximations.

4.4 GLM Posterior

The Laplace approximation in GLMs (SectionÂ 2.2) naturally generalizes the exact posterior distribution in linear models (SectionÂ 2.1). We generalize TheoremÂ 2 to GLMs along the same lines.

Proof.

The proof is in SectionÂ A.4 and comprises four steps. First, we fix tğ‘¡titalic_t and apply approximation (6). Similarly to TheoremÂ 2, the distributions in TheoremÂ 4 mix evidence with the diffusion model prior. However, this is done implicitly in ğ™¸ğšğ™»ğš‚ğ™¸ğšğ™»ğš‚\tt IRLStypewriter_IRLS. 6 Experiments

We conduct three experiments: synthetic problems in 2222 dimensions (SectionsÂ 6.2 andÂ C.1), a recommender system (SectionÂ 6.3), and a classification problem (SectionÂ C.2). In addition, we conduct an ablation study in SectionÂ C.3, where we vary the number of training samples for the diffusion prior and the number of diffusion stages Tğ‘‡Titalic_T.

6.1 Experimental Setup

We have four baselines. Three baselines are variants of contextual Thompson sampling [11, 3]: with an uninformative Gaussian prior (ğšƒğš‚ğšƒğš‚\tt TStypewriter_TS), a learned Gaussian prior (ğšƒğšğš—ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğšƒğšğš—ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS), and a learned Gaussian mixture prior (ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS) [21]. The last baseline is diffusion posterior sampling (ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS) of Chung etÂ al. [12]. We implement all TS baselines as described in SectionÂ 5. The uninformative prior is ğ’©â¢(ğŸd,Id)ğ’©subscript0ğ‘‘subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}_{d},I_{d})caligraphic_N ( bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS is used only in linear bandit experiments because the logistic regression variant does not exist. The TS baselines are chosen to cover various levels of prior information. Our implementation of ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS is described in AppendixÂ D. We also experimented with frequentist baselines, such as ğ™»ğš’ğš—ğš„ğ™²ğ™±ğ™»ğš’ğš—ğš„ğ™²ğ™±\tt LinUCBtypewriter_LinUCB [1] and the Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ-greedy policy. They performed worse than ğšƒğš‚ğšƒğš‚\tt TStypewriter_TS and thus we do not report them here.

Each experiment is set up as follows. First, the prior distribution of Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is specified: it can be synthetic or estimated from real-world data. Second, we learn this distribution from 10â€‰0001000010\,00010 000 samples from it. In ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS and ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS, we follow AppendixÂ B. The number of stages is T=100ğ‘‡100T=100italic_T = 100 and the diffusion factor is Î±t=0.97subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡0.97\alpha_{t}=0.97italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.97. Since 0.97100â‰ˆ0.05superscript0.971000.050.97^{100}\approx 0.050.97 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ 0.05, most of the information in the training samples is diffused. The regressor in AppendixÂ B is a 2222-layer neural network with ReLU activations. In ğšƒğšğš—ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğšƒğšğš—ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS, we fit the mean and covariance using maximum likelihood estimation. In ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS, we fit the Gaussian mixture using scikit-learn. All algorithms are evaluated on Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sampled from the true prior.

6.2 Synthetic Experiment

The first experiment is on three synthetic problems. Each problem is a linear bandit (SectionÂ 5) with K=100ğ¾100K=100italic_K = 100 actions in d=2ğ‘‘2d=2italic_d = 2 dimensions. The reward noise is Ïƒ=2ğœ2\sigma=2italic_Ïƒ = 2. The feature vectors of actions are sampled uniformly at random from a unit ball. The prior distributions of Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in FigureÂ 2. The first is a mixture of two Gaussians and the last can be approximated well by a mixture of two Gaussians. ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS is implemented with two mixture components, which can exactly represent the first prior and approximate the last one well.

Our results are reported in FigureÂ 2. We observe two main trends. First, samples from the diffusion prior closely resemble those from the true prior. In such cases, ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS is expected to perform well and even outperforms ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚ğ™¼ğš’ğš¡ğšƒğš‚\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS, because it has a better representation of the prior. We observe this in all problems. Second, ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS diverges as the number of rounds increases. This is because ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS relies on the score of the likelihood of observations (SectionÂ 7), which tends to infinity as the number of observations increases. This happens despite tuning (AppendixÂ D). We report results on additional synthetic problems in SectionÂ C.1.

ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS should be Tğ‘‡Titalic_T times more computationally costly than ğšƒğš‚ğšƒğš‚\tt TStypewriter_TS with a Gaussian prior (SectionÂ 4.2). We observe this empirically. As an example, the average cost of 100100100100 runs of ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS on any problem in FigureÂ 2 is 12121212 seconds. The average cost of ğšƒğš‚ğšƒğš‚\tt TStypewriter_TS is 0.10.10.10.1 seconds. The computation and accuracy can be traded off, and we investigate this in SectionÂ C.3. In Problem \saycross, we vary the number of diffusion stages from T=1ğ‘‡1T=1italic_T = 1 to T=300ğ‘‡300T=300italic_T = 300. We observe that the computational cost is linear in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T and the regret drops quickly from around 85858585 at T=1ğ‘‡1T=1italic_T = 1 to 50505050 at T=25ğ‘‡25T=25italic_T = 25.

Our MovieLens results are shown in FigureÂ 3. We observe the same trends as in SectionÂ 6.2. First, samples from the diffusion prior closely resemble those from the true prior (FigureÂ 3a). We observe this trend consistently in higher dimensions, which motivated our work on online learning with more complex priors.

7 Related Work

There are two lines of related works: bandits with diffusion models and posterior sampling in diffusion models. We start with the former. Hsieh etÂ al. [22] proposed Thompson sampling with a diffusion model prior for Kğ¾Kitalic_K-armed bandits. We consider a more general setting of contextual bandits and also develop new posterior sampling approximations for it. Aouali [4] proposed and analyzed contextual bandits with a linear diffusion model prior: Î¼tâ¢(st)subscriptğœ‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡\mu_{t}(s_{t})italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (5) is linear in stsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and qâ¢(s0)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 0q(s_{0})italic_q ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Gaussian. Due to this assumption, the resulting model is just a linear Gaussian model and not a general diffusion model, as in our work.

The closest related work on posterior sampling in diffusion models is ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS of Chung etÂ al. [12]. The key idea in ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS is to sample from a diffusion model posterior by adding the score of the likelihood of observations to it. In our notation, this is âˆ‡logâ¡pâ¢(hâˆ£Î¸)âˆ‡ğ‘conditionalâ„ğœƒ\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)âˆ‡ roman_log italic_p ( italic_h âˆ£ italic_Î¸ ), where pâ¢(hâˆ£Î¸)ğ‘conditionalâ„ğœƒp(h\mid\theta)italic_p ( italic_h âˆ£ italic_Î¸ ) is defined in AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2. Note that âˆ‡logâ¡pâ¢(hâˆ£Î¸)âˆ‡ğ‘conditionalâ„ğœƒ\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)âˆ‡ roman_log italic_p ( italic_h âˆ£ italic_Î¸ ) grows linearly in Nğ‘Nitalic_N. Therefore, ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS becomes unstable as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\inftyitalic_N â†’ âˆ. See our empirical results in SectionÂ 6.2 and the implementation of ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS in AppendixÂ D, which was tuned to improve its stability. Other methods for posterior sampling in diffusion models have been proposed recently: a sequential Monte Carlo approximation for the conditional reverse process [52], a variant of ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS with an uninformative prior [37], a pseudo-inverse approximation to the likelihood of evidence [47], and posterior sampling in latent diffusion models [40]. All of these methods rely on the score of the likelihood âˆ‡logâ¡pâ¢(hâˆ£Î¸)âˆ‡ğ‘conditionalâ„ğœƒ\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)âˆ‡ roman_log italic_p ( italic_h âˆ£ italic_Î¸ ) and thus become unstable as the number of observations Nğ‘Nitalic_N increases. Our posterior approximations do not have this issue because they are based on the product of prior and evidence distributions (TheoremsÂ 2 andÂ 4), and thus gradient-free. They work well across different levels of uncertainty (SectionÂ 6) and do not require tuning.

We also wanted to note that posterior sampling is a special from of guiding generation in diffusion models. Other approaches include conditional pre-training [15], a constraint in the reverse process [17], refining the null-space content [50], solving an optimization problem that pushes the reverse process towards evidence [46], and aligning the reverse process with the prompt [7].

8 Conclusions

We propose posterior sampling approximations for diffusion models priors. These approximations are contextual, and can be implemented efficiently in linear models and GLMs. We analyze them and evaluate them empirically on contextual bandit problems.

Our work focuses on developing novel posterior approximations rather than a regret analysis. This is because the existing approximations are unstable and may diverge in the online setting (SectionsÂ 7 andÂ 6.2). A proper regret bound for ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS would require analyzing two errors. The first error arises because the reverse process reverses the forward process only approximately (AppendixÂ B). The second error arises because our posteriors are only approximate (SectionÂ 4.3). That being said, prior works already provided general insights on the utility of complex priors. For instance, Russo and Van Roy [42] proved a Oâ¢(Î“â¢Hâ¢(Aâˆ—)â¢n)ğ‘‚Î“ğ»subscriptğ´ğ‘›O(\sqrt{\Gamma H(A_{*})n})italic_O ( square-root start_ARG roman_Î“ italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_n end_ARG ) regret bound for a linear bandit, where Î“Î“\Gammaroman_Î“ is the maximum ratio of regret to information gain and Hâ¢(Aâˆ—)ğ»subscriptğ´H(A_{*})italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the entropy of the distribution of the optimal action under the prior. In short, the bound says that a lower entropy Hâ¢(Aâˆ—)ğ»subscriptğ´H(A_{*})italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which reflects how concentrated the prior is, yields a lower regret.

Finally, we believe that our ideas can be extended beyond GLMs. The key idea in SectionÂ 4.4 is to use the Laplace approximation of the likelihood. This approximation can be computed exactly in GLMs. More generally though, it is a good approximation whenever the likelihood can be approximated well by a single Gaussian distribution. By the central limit theorem, under appropriate conditions, this is expected for any observation model when the number of observations is large.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

This section contains three additional experiments.

C.1 Additional Synthetic Problems

In SectionÂ 6.2, we show results for three hand-selected problems out of six. We report results on the other three problems in FigureÂ 4. We observe the same trends as in SectionÂ 6.2. The only minor change is that ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚ğ™³ğ™¿ğš‚\tt DPStypewriter_DPS does not diverge on the last problem.

C.2 MNIST Experiment

The next experiment is on the MNIST dataset [30], where the mean reward is estimated by a classifier. We start with learning an MLP-based multi-way classifier for digits and extract d=8ğ‘‘8d=8italic_d = 8 dimensional embeddings of all digits in the dataset, which are used as feature vectors in our experiment. We generate a distribution over model parameters Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows: (1) we choose a random positive label, assign it reward 1111, and assign reward âˆ’11-1- 1 to all other labels; (2) we subsample a random dataset of size 20202020, with 50%percent5050\%50 % positive and 50%percent5050\%50 % negative labels; (3) we train a linear model, which gives us a single Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We repeat this 10â€‰0001000010\,00010 000 times and get a distribution over Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We consider both linear and logistic bandits. In both, the model parameter Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is initially sampled from the prior. In each round, K=10ğ¾10K=10italic_K = 10 random actions are chosen randomly from all digits. In the linear bandit, the mean reward for digit xğ‘¥xitalic_x is xâŠ¤â¢Î¸âˆ—superscriptğ‘¥topsubscriptğœƒx^{\top}\theta_{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the reward noise is Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1italic_Ïƒ = 1. In the logistic bandit, the mean reward is gâ¢(xâŠ¤â¢Î¸âˆ—)ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¥topsubscriptğœƒg(x^{\top}\theta_{*})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where gğ‘”gitalic_g is a sigmoid.

Our MNIST results are reported in FigureÂ 5. We observe again that ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚ğ™³ğš’ğšğšğšƒğš‚\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS has a lower regret than all baselines, because the learned prior captures the underlying distribution of Î¸âˆ—subscriptğœƒ\theta_{*}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUBSCRIPT well. We note that both the prior and diffusion prior distributions exhibit a strong cluster structure (FigureÂ 5a), where each cluster represents one label.

C.3 Ablation Studies

We conduct three ablation studies on the cross problem in FigureÂ 2.

In all experiments, the number of samples for training diffusion priors was 10â€‰0001000010\,00010 000. In FigureÂ 6a, we vary it from 100100100100 to 10â€‰0001000010\,00010 000. We observe that the regret decreases as the number of samples increases, due to learning a more accurate prior approximation. It stabilizes around 3â€‰00030003\,0003 000 training samples. We conclude that the quality of the learned prior approximation has a major impact on regret.

In all experiments, the number of diffusion stages was T=100ğ‘‡100T=100italic_T = 100. In FigureÂ 6b, we vary it from 1111 to 300300300300 and observe its impact on regret. The regret at T=1ğ‘‡1T=1italic_T = 1 is high, but then it drops quickly up to T=25ğ‘‡25T=25italic_T = 25. It stabilizes around T=100ğ‘‡100T=100italic_T = 100, which we used in our experiments. In FigureÂ 6c, we vary Tğ‘‡Titalic_T from 1111 to 300300300300 and observe its impact on the computation time of posterior sampling. As suggested in SectionÂ 4.2, it increases linearly with Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. The main contribution to the computation time are Tğ‘‡Titalic_T calls to the neural network regressor.
